title: 108_hr282
content: The "Education Freedom Act" is cited as the short title. A new section is added to the Internal Revenue Code, providing a credit for contributions benefiting elementary and secondary schools. The "Education Freedom Act" adds a new section to the Internal Revenue Code, allowing a tax credit of 50% for qualified charitable contributions made by taxpayers, with limitations based on filing status and type of taxpayer. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code allows a tax credit of 50% for qualified charitable contributions, limited by the total amount of the taxpayer's contributions or a specific limitation amount. Qualified charitable contributions include cash donations to education investment organizations or schools at the elementary or secondary level. The term 'education investment organization' refers to organizations that disburse grants for qualified elementary and secondary education expenses, with at least 90% of their annual income dedicated to such expenses. Qualified expenses are defined in section 530(b)(4) of the Internal Revenue Code. The Internal Revenue Code section 530(b)(4) defines qualified elementary and secondary education expenses. Special rules in subsection (d) include denial of double benefit and limitations on the tax credit allowed for contributions. The Internal Revenue Code section 530(b)(4) defines qualified elementary and secondary education expenses. Special rules in subsection (d) include denial of double benefit and limitations on the tax credit allowed for contributions. Under section 1397E, controlled groups are treated as one taxpayer for purposes of this section. Taxpayers may elect to have the credit not apply for any taxable year. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2003. A new section, SEC. 117A, grants exclusion from gross income of grants from education investment organizations. SEC. 117A grants exclusion from gross income of grants for qualified elementary and secondary education expenses from education investment organizations. Effective for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2003. SEC. 4 amends the definition of qualified elementary and secondary education expenses to include public, private, religious, or home schools. Effective for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2003.
